EconomicImpact.li: Ongoing large-scale crisis, impact has not been evaluated as of July 5th 2013.
Estimates over 500 Billion INR (10 Billion USD)

ResourcesNeeded.li: Prime Minister of India undertook an aerial survey of the affected areas and announced 1,000 crore (US$170 million) aid package for disaster relief efforts in the state.
The Indian Army and the National Disaster Response Force were deployed to evacuate stranded people on June 15th 2013.
The Indian Airforce has flown hundreds of sorties every day to airdrop food and fuel for trapped villages.

WaysToHelp.li: Donate to Prime Minister's Relief Fund
Google Person Finder
List of Helpline Numbers

Common.Summary: In June 2013, the North Indian states of Uttarakhand and Himachal Pradesh, some regions of Western Nepal and their adjoining areas experienced heavy rainfall that triggered devastating floods and landslides. As of 29 June 2013, more than 1,000 people have died with many more missing. Damage to bridges and roads left over 70,000 pilgrims and tourists trapped in various places. The Indian Air Force, the Army and paramilitary troops have evacuated more than 100,000 people from the flood hit areas.

HumanImpact.li: 3,500,000 people were affected and over 300,000 people were injured.
Haitian government estimated 316,000 deaths one year after the earthquake while the highest reliable death count was estimated at 220,000.
25% of civil servants in Port-au-Prince died.
Tens of thousands of refugees relocated to areas not affected.
Over 600,000 people left thier home area in Port-au-Prince and mostly stayed with host families.
At its peak, one and a half million people were living in camps including over 100,000 at critical risk from storms and flooding.

EconomicImpact.li: Over 188,383 houses were badly damaged and 105,000 were destroyed.
1,500,000 people became homeless.
4,000 schools were damaged or destroyed.
60% of Government and administrative buildings, 80% of schools in Port-au-Prince and 60% of schools in the South and West Departments were destroyed or damaged
After the quake there were 19 million cubic metres of rubble and debris in Port-au-Prince, enough to fill a line of shipping containers stretching end to end from London to Beirut.

ResourcesNeeded.li: The DEC Appeal has now raised pound 107m, two-thirds directly and one-third through its member agencies, which will be spent over three years.
DEC agencies and their partners have nearly pound 380m to spend in total from all sources
1.8million people reached by DEC funded aid.
DEC is also working on improving the water supply of 340,000 people.
DEC is also supplying drugs to five cholera treatment facilities serving 18,000 people.
DEC is also providing free medical care to 39,000 people and has improved shelters for 34,000 people.

WaysToHelp.li: Donate to the Haitian Health Foundation
Sponser a child through Save the Children
Partners in Health
Help rebuild Haiti's schools through Concern Worldwide US
Help MFK raise money for a Medicine and Food Factory
Donate to the J/P Haitian Relief Foundation

ExternalLinks.li: National Geographic Article: Haiti Earthquake Strange, Strongest in 200 Years

EconomicImpact.li: Damage was estimated at over US$10 billion, which made it the most damaging cyclone ever recorded in this basin.

ResourcesNeeded.li: The United Kingdom donated 33.5 million USD for the relief effort.
Burma made it very difficult to provide aid to the country, claiming foreign personel providing aid would violate their sovereignty.
The rice production was affected because of the cyclone and it was necesseary to aid to prevent famine.

The UN Human Settlements Programme (UN-HABITAT) reported the extent of the international response to date as less than 7 percent of the actual needs for shelter after 15 months, although emergency shelter relief efforts were well funded.

WaysToHelp.li: Sign your name to request aid

EconomicImpact.li: UN projects annual costs of 10 billion
Drug regimens cost $1,500 in developing countries, up to $15,000 in first-world countries.
Those infected are typically in the peak productivity of their lives and the loss on productiviy as the disease progresses causes billions in indirect costs.

Heavily infected nations typically enter spirals of declining GDP, causing a drop in health care support. Human capital development typically halts and even regresses as parents are unable to pass on capital to their children.

ResourcesNeeded.li: Monetary donations to subsidize drug therapy for developing countries and those who cannot afford prescriptions.
Those infected in third world countries typically do not know how the disease is transmitted, the HIV/AIDS link, etc. Education on the nature of the disease can reduce transmission rates
Programs that educate at-risk populations (sex workers, IV drug users, etc.) on methods to limit transmission, e.g. limiting sexual partners, increasing condom use, and delaying sexual debut.
Programs to help families effected by AIDS including care for orphans and income supplementation in an effort to curb human capital loss.
Testing kits to make those infected aware of their condition in an effort to limit transmission.

WaysToHelp.li: Donate to an African-focused AIDs organization.
Donate to United Nations AIDS relief program.

Citations.li: United Nations report on the societal and economic impact of AIDS
World Bank report on the long-term economic impact of AIDS
Overview of how AIDS effects Sub-Saharan African nations and preventive measures that are being taken to help.
World Bank bullet point list on AIDS worldwide impact.
WHO report on growing AIDS epidemic and ways to limit its expansion

Common.Summary: Disease of human immune system that is transferred during unprotected sex, blood, breastfeeding, and child delivery with an infected person. Believed to have originiated in Africa in the early 20th century, it is reponsible for millions of deaths. AIDs also serves as a source of discrimination and economic drain, and has profoundly impacted the countries where it is most prevelant.

EconomicImpact.li: 12 billion in direct healthcare costs
Heavily infected countries show a 33% drop in GDP growth over last 30 years compared to neighbours that have low infection rates.

ResourcesNeeded.li: Insecticides and Pesticides have historically had amazing results, virtually eliminating infections in UAE while neighboring Oman has one of the highest infection rates in the world.
Rapid diagnostic tests ensure people get treatment when they need it.
Artemisinin-based combination therapies cost arround a dollar and can cure a child within three days
Mosquito nets provide a cheap barrier at night and can reduce infection rates by up to 90 percent.

WaysToHelp.li: Donate money to subsidize drug therapy
Donate both nets and drug therapy

Citations.li: Report on the economic burden of Malaria

ExternalLinks.li: List of solutions for the Malaria crisis

Common.Summary: Malaria is a life threatening illness and a major cause of death worldwide. It exists in tropical and subtropical climates and still infects hundred of millions of people annually. It is a major drain on productivity of heavily infected nations and has a major economic impact. Nations have successfully eliminated malaria with wide use of insecticides in the past, such as DDT. Global eradication of the four types of malaria is a major goal of several globaliazed communal orginizations.

Locations.li: Diamond fields Southwest of Mutare, Zimbabwe

EconomicImpact.li: Thousands of native residents forcibly relocated
Environmental impact, poisoning of Save river
One of the world's richest diamond deposits

WaysToHelp.li: Advocate for tighter restrictions on the Kimerly Process member countries
Demand proof that a diamond is conflict-free
Ultimately, refrain from purchasing diamonds

Citations.li: BBC Article on Humans Rights violations at Zimbabwean diamond mines in 2011
Article on the UN's decision to sanction Zimbabwean diamond exports in 2006 due to human rights abuses

ExternalLinks.li: Primer on how diamonds fuel human rights violations
United Nation's attempt at preventing sale of conflict diamonds
Advocacy Group's suggestions on how to help African conflict diamond crisis

Common.Summary: Extensive diamond deposits were located in late 2006 around Marange, Zimbabwe. The government quickly moved in and displaced local residents and miners. By 2008 the Zimbabwean military was practicing many humans right violations such as forced labor, torture, and mass killings to maintain its grasp. The United Nation's Kimberly Process dispatched a reviewer in 2009 to inspect claims of widespread violations and ultimately came to a compromise with the Zimbabwean government.

EconomicImpact.li: Damages worth 5.59 Billion USD
Loss of property worth 4.33 Billion USD
Total economic impact worth 9.93 billion USD

ResourcesNeeded.li: A great deal of humanitarian aid was needed because of widespread damage of the infrastructure, shortages of food and water, and economic damage.

The main concern of humanitarian and government agencies was to provide sanitation facilities and fresh drinking water to contain the spread of diseases such as cholera, diphtheria, dysentery, typhoid and hepatitis A and B.
The World Food Programme provided food aid to more than 1.3 million people affected by the tsunami.

WaysToHelp.li: Donate to the Indian Prime Minister's Relief Fund
Donate to CARE
Americares, a non-profit emergency health organisation.

ExternalLinks.li: National Geographic Article : The Deadliest Tsunami in History ?
Wikipedia - 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami

Common.Summary: The 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake was an undersea megathrust earthquake that occurred at 00:58:53 UTC on Sunday, 26 December 2004, with an epicentre off the west coast of Sumatra, Indonesia. The quake itself is known by the scientific community as the Sumatra earthquake.The resulting tsunami was given various names, including the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami, South Asian tsunami, Indonesian tsunami, and the Boxing Day tsunami. The earthquake was caused when the Indian Plate was subducted by the Burma Plate and triggered a series of devastating tsunamis along the coasts of most landmasses bordering the Indian Ocean, killing over 230,000 people in fourteen countries, and inundating coastal communities with waves up to 30 meters (98 ft) high. It was one of the deadliest natural disasters in recorded history. Indonesia was the hardest-hit country, followed by Sri Lanka,India, and Thailand. With a magnitude of Mw 9.1, it is the third largest earthquake ever recorded on a seismograph. The earthquake had the longest duration of faulting ever observed, between 8.3 and 10 minutes. It caused the entire planet to vibrate as much as 1 centimetre (0.4 inches)and triggered other earthquakes as far away as Alaska. Its epicentre was between Simeulue and mainland Indonesia.

HumanImpact.li: Estimated between 1,969 and 3,461 dead (as of 8 February 2013).

EconomicImpact.li: It is hard to estimate the economic impact of the drone attacks. Obviously there is a socio-economic impact for the people having to live under the constant threat of drone attacks, but again it is hard to quantitatively define that impact.

ResourcesNeeded.li: Given that this is a CIA operation, I am not sure there is much any one individual can do to stop the drone attacks besides contacting their appropriate govermental officials.
There are two clinics put on by Stanford and NYU Law Schools (http://www.livingunderdrones.org/about-the-clinics/), but again these are more for students and faculty of the given institutions.

WaysToHelp.li: Contact your local Senators and Representative

ExternalLinks.li: Stanford International Human Rights and Conflict Resolution Clinic

Common.Summary: Controversial president of Zimbabwe since 1987. Zimbabwe's GDP/C has shrunk by more than half over his reign, and has included claims of racism, genocide, and other civil rights violations. Critics claim that he was reponsible for the massacre of 150 illegal miners and ongoing civil rights violations around the Mutare diamond fields.

Citations.li: India PM Singh takes oath for second term :Reuters

ExternalLinks.li: BBC Profile: Prime Minister of India

Common.Summary: Manmohan Singh (born 26 September 1932) is the 13th and current Prime Minister of India. Singh holds a doctorate in economics from Oxford university, and has served as an advisor to the Ministry of Foreign Trade, India (1966-69), Governer of the Reserve Bank of India (1982-85) and Deputy Chairman of the Planning Commission (1985-87), before being appointed the Minister of Finance in the Indian cabinet in 1991. As the Minister of finance, Singh carried out several structural reforms that liberalised India's economy. In 2004, Singh was elected as the Prime Minister of India. His government has since executed several key legislations and projects including the Rural Health Mission, Unique Identification Authority, Rural Employment Guarantee scheme and the Right to Information Act.
Famous founder of Microsoft and previously the richest man in the world, Bill Gates now spends most of his time heading his philanthropy organization, The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation

Citations.li: U.N. official slams U.S. as stingy over aid

Common.Summary: Jan Egeland (born 12 September 1957 in Stavanger, Norway) is a Norwegian politician from the Labour party. He is the Deputy Director of Human Rights Watch and the Director of Human Rights Watch Europe. Egeland took up the position as director of the Norwegian Institute of International Affairs on 1 September 2007. Egeland also holds a post as Professor II at theUniversity of Stavanger. Egeland was the United Nations Undersecretary-General for Humanitarian Affairs and Emergency Relief Coordinator from June 2003 to December 2006. Egeland was appointed bySecretary-General Kofi Annan and succeeded Kenzo Oshima. He traveled extensively, drawing attention to humanitarian emergencies. Egeland was also Secretary General of the Norwegian Red Cross. He served as State Secretary in the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs (1990 to 1997) and was Chair of Amnesty International Norway..

History.li: Since the Fund was created in 2002, public sector pledges have totaled USD 28.3 billion (95 percent of all pledges). The remaining USD 1.6 billion (5 percent) has been pledged from the private sector or other financing initiatives.

Common.Summary: The Global Fund is an innovative financing institution that provides funding to countries to support programs that prevent, treat and care for people with HIV and AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria.

History.li: Founded in 1948 by the then Prime Minister of India, Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru.

Citations.li: 'Affected people in Uttarakhand need our help', says PM
Uttarakhand floods: Donate to help victims, appeals Prime Minister Manmohan Singh

Common.Summary: In pursuance of an appeal by the then Prime Minister, Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru in January, 1948, the Prime Minister's National Relief Fund (PMNRF) was established with public contributions to assist displaced persons from Pakistan. The resources of the PMNRF are now utilized primarily to render immediate relief to families of those killed in natural calamities like floods, cyclones and earthquakes, etc. and to the victims of the major accidents and riots. Assistance from PMNRF is also rendered for medical treatment like heart surgeries, kidney transplantation, cancer treatment, etc. The fund consists entirely of public contributions and does not get any budgetary support. The corpus of the fund is invested with banks in fixed deposits. Disbursements are made with the approval of the Prime Minister.

Organization.Name: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

History.li: The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) is a United Nations (UN) body formed in December 1991 by General Assembly Resolution 46/182. The resolution was designed to strengthen the UN's response to complex emergencies and natural disasters by creating the Department of Humanitarian Affairs (DHA), and replacing the Office of the United Nations Disaster Relief Coordinator, which had been formed in 1972. In 1998, due to reorganisation, DHA merged into the OCHA and was designed to be the UN focal point on major disasters. Its mandate was expanded to also include the coordination of humanitarian response, policy development and humanitarian advocacy.

Citations.li: WHD: Life and death in Tsunami-hit Indonesia

Common.Summary: OCHA is headed by the Undersecretary-General for Humanitarian Affairs and Emergency Relief Coordinator, currently Valerie Amos. As of 2007 OCHA has some 1,064 staff, distributed across the world. Major OCHA country offices are located in Afghanistan, Burundi, Central African Republic, Chad, Colombia, Democratic Republic of Congo, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Ivory Coast, Palestinian territories, Sri Lanka, Sudan (including a sub-office in Southern Sudan's capital Juba), Uganda, and Zimbabwe, while regional offices are located in Panama City, Dakar, Cairo, Johannesburg, and Bangkok. OCHA also has some liaison and support staff in New York and Geneva.

History.li: Founded in 1945 after World War II.

Common.Summary: International organization containing 193 member countries as an advocate of peace and cooperation between member states.
